para.paratext: By statute, the standard of proof in criminal cases is “whether there is sufficient evidence to satisfy the mind and conscience beyond a reasonable doubt.”[1] Absent a request otherwise, a court giving a jury charge based on the Code section definition of reasonable doubt is adequate.[2] However, it is not necessarily error to give an extended definition of beyond a reasonable doubt. In a case where the evidence is circumstantial, the proven facts have to be consistent with the hypothesis of guilt and exclude every reasonable hypothesis except the defendant's guilt.[3]

In Cage v. Louisiana,[4] the United States Supreme Court held that a jury instruction regarding guilt beyond a reasonable doubt violates the Due Process Clause if the charge can be interpreted as instructing that “moral certainty” (rather than evidentiary certainty) is the standard.

However, a reference to “moral and reasonable certainty” does not render a jury instruction on reasonable doubt unconstitutional, if the jury charge properly defines reasonable doubt.[5] In fact, a court may define the burden of “beyond a reasonable doubt” by explaining that “the State is not required to prove the guilt of the accused beyond all doubt or to a mathematical certainty” and that “[m]oral and reasonable certainty is all that can be expected in a legal investigation.”[6]

In Pilcher v. State,[7] the trial court instructed the jury that “the State is not required to prove the guilt of the accused beyond all doubt or to a mathematical certainty.” On appeal, the defendant argued that the mathematical terminology added by the trial court lessened the degree of proof necessary to convict by suggesting to the jury that something less than “beyond a reasonable doubt” would be sufficient. The Georgia Court of Appeals rejected this argument, relying on United Supreme Court precedent, which held that “taken as a whole,” an instruction that mathematical certainty is not required for conviction “correctly conveyed the concept of reasonable doubt to the jury.”[8]
However, the Georgia Supreme Court has noted that the better practice in charging the jury on reasonable doubt is to omit the phrase “moral and reasonable certainty.”[9] As the court explained:

What is perceived as “moral” may differ from group to group, from class to class, and from individual to individual. This diversity renders any precise definition of “moral certainty” elusive, and any uniformity of interpretation by jurors unlikely. Further, because the term “reasonable” is inherently equivocal, it is conceivable that a juror could be reasonably certain of an element of a crime, and at the same time harbor a reasonable doubt as to that element. Hence, a juror who heard the phrase “reasonable certainty” might apply a lesser standard of proof than guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.[10]
The Georgia Suggested Pattern Jury Instruction—Criminal 1.20.10 offers a reasonable doubt instruction that states:

[T]he State is not required to prove the guilt of the accused beyond all doubt or to a mathematical certainty. A reasonable doubt means just what it says. A reasonable doubt is a doubt of a fair-minded, impartial juror honestly seeking the truth. A reasonable doubt is a doubt based upon common sense and reason. It does not mean a vague or arbitrary doubt but is a doubt for which a reason can be given, arising from a consideration of the evidence, a lack of evidence, or a conflict in the evidence.[11]

Instead of being a vague, fanciful, or speculative doubt, reasonable doubt is a substantial doubt that arises from the evidence and that reasonable, fair-minded, and honest men would entertain under all the facts and circumstances of the case.[12] Clearly, it would be error to charge in a criminal case that the state could carry the burden of persuasion by a preponderance of the evidence.[13] It is also error to charge that the jury could find the defendant guilty of murder “for any reason satisfactory to the jury.”[14]

Although the pattern instruction, supra, refers to an “impartial juror honestly seeking the truth,” an instruction that allows the jury to convict or acquit on an “honest belief” in guilt or innocence lessens the standard too far towards the civil standard.[15] In Ward v. State,[16] the Georgia Supreme Court explained that, “[b]y suggesting that the jury was authorized to convict based upon an ‘honest belief’ of guilt, rather than a determination that there was an absence of any reasonable doubt of guilt, the trial court effectively authorized the jurors to convict appellant if, after balancing the evidence for themselves, they concluded that the State's evidence of guilt was more persuasive than appellant's evidence introduced in her defense.”

In Monroe v. State,[17] the trial court defined “reasonable doubt” and then advised the jury “if that doubt does not exist in your minds as to the guilt of the defendant, then the jury has a responsibility to convict.” This was not reversible error, but the Georgia Supreme Court strongly discouraged the use of language in a charge which suggests that the jury has a “duty to convict” in the absence of reasonable doubt. The court further stated that the “better practice” is to use the pattern jury instruction which informs the jury that it would be “authorized to convict” in the absence of reasonable doubt.[18]

In Taylor v. Kentucky,[19] the trial judge charged on the requirement that the prosecution carry its burden of persuasion beyond a reasonable doubt but refused a request for a charge on the presumption of innocence. This was error since the failure to charge on the presumption of innocence violated the defendant's right to a fair trial under the 14th Amendment.

However, Taylor v. Kentucky was limited in Kentucky v. Whorton[20] where the court held that a failure to give a requested charge on the presumption of innocence would not in and of itself violate the Constitution. The court must evaluate the totality of the circumstances to determine if the defendant received a fair trial. The error was harmless in this case.

In every criminal case, venue must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt.[21] Georgia requires that venue in criminal cases must be laid in the county in which the crime allegedly occurred.[22] Evidence of venue may be direct or circumstantial. When venue is proved by circumstantial evidence, it is enough if the fact of venue is properly inferable from all the evidence.[23]

In cases where there is jury misconduct, as in Edge v. State,[24] where the jurors consulted their phones to obtain distances between properties and pictures of the properties involved during jury deliberations, it is the state's burden to overcome the presumption of harm to the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt.

In Jackson v. Virginia,[25] the United States Supreme Court extended habeas corpus review where an applicant for federal habeas corpus claimed that a state trial convicted him on insufficient evidence. The habeas corpus judge must determine whether the facts and record evidence support a finding of guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. After Jackson, appellate courts now include in many criminal cases a statement to the effect that “[t]he evidence was sufficient to support the verdict of the jury finding appellant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.”[26]

In Littles v. Balkcom,[27] the Georgia Supreme Court held that the issue of sufficiency of the evidence under Jackson could not be raised in a state habeas corpus application. Justice Hill, dissenting, stated that Jackson v. Virginia had given constitutional status to claims concerning the sufficiency of the evidence. The United States Supreme Court took this view in Pilon v. Bordenkircher[28] where it stated: “The Court in Jackson held that this constitutional requirement can be effectuated only if a federal habeas corpus court, in assessing the sufficiency of the evidence to support a state-court conviction, inquires ‘whether, after viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, any rational trier of fact could have found the essential elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt.’”

Throughout the 1980s, cases trended toward requiring a higher standard of proof in habeas corpus reviews. The Georgia Supreme court held in Spivey v. State[29] that a criminal defendant must prove his mental illness beyond a reasonable doubt for a verdict of “guilty but mentally ill.” The court reversed the Georgia Court of Appeals[30] in In re Crane,[31] stating, “After a consideration of the majority view as set forth in the above authorities, we have concluded that the standard of proof in criminal contempt cases is the beyond-reasonable-doubt standard, and that the preponderance-of-evidence (civil) standard will no longer be followed in this state.”
The proper standard of review on an insufficient evidence claim is whether, given the facts, a rational trier of fact could have found the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.[32]
Lingo v. State, 96 Ga. App. 379, 100 S.E.2d 116 (1957); Betsill v. State, 98 Ga. App. 695, 106 S.E.2d 323 (1958).

It was reversible error for the trial court in a theft case to charge the jury that they could infer guilt unless there was from the evidence a reasonable explanation of possession consistent with a plea of innocence. The Court of Appeals held that this charge was not a sufficient restatement of (former) O.C.G.A. § 24-4-6 in that the jury was not adequately instructed that the state's circumstantial evidence of guilt should “exclude every other reasonable hypothesis save that of the guilt of the accused.” McChargue v. State, 209 Ga. App. 612, 434 S.E.2d 153 (1993).
Also see Jenkins v. State, 209 Ga. App. 19, 432 S.E.2d 270 (1993).

However, a request for a charge regarding two equal theories, one of guilt and the other of innocence, is not the equivalent of a request under (former) O.C.G.A. § 24-4-6, and a court can reject such a charge. Kelly v. State, 212 Ga. App. 278, 442 S.E.2d 462 (1994).

Cage v. Louisiana, 498 U.S. 39, 111 S. Ct. 328, 329, 112 L. Ed. 2d 339, 341 (1990) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Estelle v. McGuire, 502 U.S. 62, 112 S. Ct. 475, 116 L. Ed. 2d 385, 33 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 305 (1991)) (per curiam).

See Starr v. State, 201 Ga. App. 73, 410 S.E.2d 180 (1991); Brown v. State, 264 Ga. 48, 49–50, 441 S.E.2d 235 (1994); Armstrong v. State, 265 Ga. 18, 19, 453 S.E.2d 442 (1995); Fagan v. State, 283 Ga. App. 784, 643 S.E.2d 268 (2007) (accord).

Brown v. State, 264 Ga. 48, 49, 441 S.E.2d 235 (1994) (“[w]here, as here, the jury charge properly defined reasonable doubt, a reference to a ‘moral and reasonable certainty’ did not lessen the burden of proof necessary to obtain a conviction, and therefore did not violate the Due Process Clause”).
See also Boyd v. State, 230 Ga. App. 314, 497 S.E.2d 3 (1998).

Like the phrase “moral certainty,” the phrase “reasonable certainty” describes evidence necessary to establish proof beyond reasonable doubt. In Baldwin v. State, 264 Ga. 664, 449 S.E.2d 853 (1994), the Georgia Supreme Court found no reasonable likelihood that the jury interpreted the trial court's reference to “reasonable certainty” as allowing conviction on evidence meeting lesser standard of proof than that of beyond reasonable doubt.

But see Vance v. State, 262 Ga. 236, 238, 416 S.E.2d 516 (1992) (overruled on other grounds by, Sterling v. State, 267 Ga. 209, 477 S.E.2d 807 (1996)) (discouraging the use of the term “reasonable certainty” in defining reasonable doubt).
Pilcher v. State, 214 Ga. App. 395, 396, 448 S.E.2d 61 (1994).
Pilcher v. State, 214 Ga. App. 395, 396–397, 448 S.E.2d 61 (1994) (relying upon Victor v. Nebraska, 511 U.S. 1, 114 S. Ct. 1239, 127 L. Ed. 2d 583 (1994)).
Vance v. State, 262 Ga. 236, 416 S.E.2d 516 (1992) (overruled on other grounds by, Sterling v. State, 267 Ga. 209, 477 S.E.2d 807 (1996)).
Vance v. State, 262 Ga. 236, 238, 416 S.E.2d 516 (1992) (overruled on other grounds by, Sterling v. State, 267 Ga. 209, 477 S.E.2d 807 (1996)).
See also Andrews v. State, 236 Ga. App. 152, 511 S.E.2d 258 (1999); Johnson v. State, 245 Ga. App. 761, 538 S.E.2d 850 (2000) (approving the use of almost identical language).
Brantley v. State, 133 Ga. 264, 65 S.E. 426 (1909); Thurmond v. State, 198 Ga. 410, 416, 31 S.E.2d 804 (1944).
McDonald v. State, 104 Ga. App. 578, 122 S.E.2d 145 (1961); Cross v. State, 150 Ga. App. 206, 257 S.E.2d 330 (1979).
Jennings v. State, 212 Ga. 58, 90 S.E.2d 401 (1955).
Ward v. State, 271 Ga. 62, 515 S.E.2d 392 (1999); Williams v. State, 271 Ga. 204, 515 S.E.2d 841 (1999).

See also Berry v. State, 267 Ga. 476, 480 S.E.2d 32 (1997); Lemay v. State, 264 Ga. 263, 443 S.E.2d 274 (1994); Caldwell v. State, 263 Ga. 560, 436 S.E.2d 488 (1993); Marion v. State, 263 Ga. 358, 434 S.E.2d 463 (1993); Taylor v. State, 262 Ga. 584, 422 S.E.2d 430 (1992).
Taylor v. Kentucky, 436 U.S. 478, 98 S. Ct. 1930, 56 L. Ed. 2d 468 (1978); Reaves v. State, 146 Ga. App. 409, 246 S.E.2d 427 (1978).
Kentucky v. Whorton, 441 U.S. 786, 99 S. Ct. 2088, 60 L. Ed. 2d 640 (1979).

Kentucky v. Whorton was considered in Schuh v. State, 150 Ga. App. 700, 258 S.E.2d 328 (1979), but the federal question was not considered since the court held that it would be reversible error under O.C.G.A. § 16-1-5 (former GCA § 26-501) not to charge on the presumption of innocence. The charge in this case was proper.
Crawford v. State, 297 Ga. 680, 777 S.E.2d 463 (2015); McMullen v. State, 300 Ga. 173, 794 S.E.2d 118 (2016).
Slaughter v. State, 345 Ga. App. 790, 815 S.E.2d 141 (2018).
Worthen v. State, 304 Ga. 862, 823 S.E.2d 291 (2019).
Edge v. State, 345 Ga. App. 794, 815 S.E.2d 146 (2018).
Jackson v. Virginia, 443 U.S. 307, 99 S. Ct. 2781, 61 L. Ed. 2d 560 (1979); Moore v. Duckworth, 443 U.S. 713, 99 S. Ct. 3088, 61 L. Ed. 2d 865 (1979).
Jackson v. State, 244 Ga. 276, 260 S.E.2d 15 (1979) (citing Jackson v. Virginia, 443 U.S. 307, 99 S. Ct. 2781, 61 L. Ed. 2d 560 (1979)).
See, e.g., Parrish v. State, 244 Ga. 210, 259 S.E.2d 464 (1979); Stinson v. State, 244 Ga. 219, 259 S.E.2d 471 (1979).
In Hartley v. State, 152 Ga. App. 337, 262 S.E.2d 608 (1979), the evidence was not sufficient to satisfy Jackson v. Virginia, so the trial court was reversed.
Littles v. Balkcom, 245 Ga. 285, 264 S.E.2d 219 (1980).
Pilon v. Bordenkircher, 444 U.S. 1, 100 S. Ct. 7, 62 L. Ed. 2d 1 (1979).
See Holloway v. McElroy, 632 F.2d 605 (5th Cir. 1980).
In re Crane, 171 Ga. App. 31, 318 S.E.2d 709 (1984).
Nixon v. State, 349 Ga. App. 277, 826 S.E.2d 150 (2019).
